title: Chapter 1: The Alphabet and Basic Pronunciation
description: Learn the alphabet and fundamental pronunciation rules of the target language. Practice sounds and phonetic symbols to build a strong foundation for speaking and understanding. Focus on distinguishing key sounds and practicing basic phonetic exercises.

conversations.title: Alphabet Practice: Spelling Names (Greeting)
conversations.description: Practice spelling names using the alphabet and basic greetings. Focus on clear pronunciation of individual letters.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to meet someone new.
* Greet the other person and ask for their name.
* Ask them to spell their first name.
* Spell your name and then say goodbye.
* Focus on correctly pronouncing each letter.
* Vocabulary to use: "Hello", "My name is...", "What's your name?", "Can you spell that?", "Goodbye", "Nice to meet you."

conversations.title: Alphabet Practice: Giving Address Information
conversations.description: Practice providing address information, emphasizing correct spelling and pronunciation of street names and numbers. This expands on the initial alphabet practice.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to give directions to someone over the phone. 
* Ask them for their current address or the address to which they would like you to send the mail.
* Confirm the address by reading it back to them, spelling out any unfamiliar words or numbers.
* Vocabulary to use: "Address", "Street", "Number", "Is that correct?", "Let me spell that for you.", "A as in apple, B as in boy..."
* Build on the previous conversation's vocabulary and focus on longer strings of letters and numbers.

conversations.title: Ordering Coffee: Focusing on Vowel Pronunciation
conversations.description: Practice ordering coffee while paying close attention to vowel pronunciation in common words like "coffee", "milk", "sugar", and numbers for quantities. Builds on the previous conversations.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to order coffee at a cafe.
* Clearly state your order, paying attention to the pronunciation of vowels in words like "coffee", "milk", and "sugar".
* Use numbers to specify quantities (e.g., "two coffees").
* The other person is the barista.
* Vocabulary to use: "I would like", "Please", "Coffee", "Milk", "Sugar", "One", "Two", "Three", "Thank you.", "How much will that be?"
* Focus on differentiating between similar vowel sounds.

conversations.title: Booking a Hotel Room: Consonant and Vowel Sounds
conversations.description: Practice booking a hotel room, focusing on distinguishing consonant and vowel sounds. Emphasize clear communication of dates and room types. Builds on the previous conversations.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to book a hotel room over the phone.
* Clearly state the dates you need the room and the type of room you want (e.g., single, double).
* Pay attention to the pronunciation of consonants and vowels in words like "room", "date", "single", and "double".
* The other person is the hotel receptionist.
* Vocabulary to use: "I would like to book", "Room", "Single", "Double", "Date", "Night", "Check-in", "Check-out", "Available?", "How much is it per night?"
* Practice distinguishing between similar consonant sounds.

conversations.title: Asking for Directions: Full Sentences and General Pronunciation
conversations.description: Practice asking for directions using full sentences, focusing on overall pronunciation clarity and fluency. Review all previous concepts: alphabet, vowels, consonants, and phonetics. Builds on the previous conversations.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to ask someone for directions.
* Use full sentences to ask where something is (e.g., "Where is the nearest train station?").
* Clearly understand the directions given, paying attention to the pronunciation of street names, "left", "right", and "straight".
* The other person is a passerby.
* Vocabulary to use: "Excuse me", "Where is the...?", "How do I get to...?", "Left", "Right", "Straight", "Thank you", "Is it far?", "Could you repeat that, please?"
* Focus on speaking clearly and fluently, incorporating all previous pronunciation practice.

title: Chapter 2: Greetings and Introductions
description: Master basic greetings like 'hello,' 'goodbye,' and 'how are you?' Learn to introduce yourself and others using simple phrases. Practice polite greetings and farewells in different contexts, such as formal and informal settings.

conversations.title: Simple Greetings: Hello and Goodbye
conversations.description: Practice basic greetings and farewells in a casual setting. Focus on 'Hello,' 'Hi,' 'Goodbye,' and 'Bye.'
conversations.instructions:
* You are in a park.
* You see someone you know distantly.
* Exchange a simple greeting and farewell.
* Keep the conversation brief, focused only on greetings.
* Do not delve into other topics.
* Start the conversation with 'Hello'.
* End the conversation with 'Goodbye' or 'Bye'.

conversations.title: Greetings: How Are You?
conversations.description: Expand on basic greetings by asking and answering 'How are you?' Practice responding with 'I'm fine, thank you,' and similar phrases.
conversations.instructions:
* You are in a coffee shop.
* You are meeting a friend for a quick coffee.
* Greet each other, ask 'How are you?', and respond appropriately.
* Keep the conversation relatively short.
* Start with 'Hello' or 'Hi'.
* End with 'Goodbye' or 'Bye', or 'See you later'.

conversations.title: Self-Introduction: Name Only
conversations.description: Learn to introduce yourself by stating your name. Use phrases like 'My name is...' and 'I am...'
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a networking event.
* Introduce yourself to someone new.
* State your name clearly using 'My name is...' or 'I am...'.
* Respond to the other person's introduction with 'Nice to meet you'.
* Do not delve into other topics beyond introductions initially.
* Start with 'Hello' or 'Hi'.
* End with 'Nice to meet you'.

conversations.title: Introductions: Name and Occupation
conversations.description: Introduce yourself and state your occupation. Use phrases like 'I am a...' or 'I work as a...'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a conference.
* Introduce yourself to another attendee.
* State your name and your profession.
* Ask the other person for their name and profession using 'And you?'
* For example, "Hello, my name is John, and I am a software engineer. And you?"
* Do not delve into excessive detail about your job, but do mention it.

conversations.title: Formal Introductions: Introducing Others
conversations.description: Practice introducing two people to each other in a formal setting. Use phrases like 'This is...' and 'May I introduce you to...'
conversations.instructions:
* You are hosting a dinner party.
* Introduce two guests who do not know each other.
* Use formal language, such as 'May I introduce you to...' or 'This is...'.
* Respond appropriately when introduced, using phrases like 'Pleased to meet you' or 'How do you do?'.
* Guide the conversation to keep it focused on the introduction initially.
* Start by addressing one person by their name.
* The conversation may expand beyond the initial greeting.

title: Chapter 3: Numbers and Counting
description: Learn numbers from 1 to 100 and beyond. Practice counting, telling time, and using numbers in everyday situations like giving phone numbers or prices. Focus on cardinal and ordinal numbers, and practicing listening comprehension of numbers.

conversations.title: Conversation 1: Basic Counting Practice (1-20)
conversations.description: Practice counting from 1 to 20. Focus on clear pronunciation and memorization of numbers.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a teacher helping a student learn to count.
* Start by asking the student to count to 10, correct any mistakes, and encourage them.
* Then, have the student count from 11 to 20. Again, provide corrections and encouragement.
* Practice repetition if needed. Ask the student to count forwards and backwards, and also select numbers to repeat.
* End the conversation with a positive affirmation, praising the student's effort.

conversations.title: Conversation 2: Counting to 100 (Tens)
conversations.description: Practice counting in multiples of ten, up to one hundred. Reinforce the structure of 'ty' numbers (twenty, thirty, etc.).
conversations.instructions:
* You are a cashier counting money.
* A customer is paying for an item, and you need to count the money out loud to confirm the amount.
* Start with tens (10, 20, 30...) until you reach the total amount.
* If the total amount is not a multiple of ten, include the remaining single-digit numbers (e.g., 'Ten, twenty, twenty-one, twenty-two').
* Respond naturally to the customer (e.g., 'Thank you', 'Here is your change').

conversations.title: Conversation 3: Giving a Phone Number
conversations.description: Practice giving and receiving a phone number clearly and accurately.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a customer at a doctor's office providing your phone number to a receptionist.
* The receptionist will ask for your phone number.
* State your phone number clearly, digit by digit. Use pauses between number groups to aid comprehension (e.g., '555...123...4567').
* Confirm the phone number if the receptionist repeats it.
* Correct any errors in the phone number if the receptionist mishears it.
* If asked, confirm your name.

conversations.title: Conversation 4: Asking and Stating Prices
conversations.description: Practice asking for and stating prices in a shop or market setting. Use numbers in the context of currency.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a vendor at a market stall.
* A customer will approach and ask for the price of various items.
* State the price clearly, including the currency (e.g., 'It costs five dollars', 'That will be ten euros fifty').
* Respond politely to any questions about the price (e.g., 'Yes, that's the best price I can offer').
* If the customer asks for multiple items, calculate and state the total price.

conversations.title: Conversation 5: Telling Time
conversations.description: Practice asking for and stating the time. Focus on 'o'clock', 'half past', 'quarter past', and 'quarter to'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a person waiting at a bus stop.
* A stranger approaches and asks you for the time.
* State the time clearly and accurately, using appropriate phrases (e.g., 'It's half past three', 'It's quarter to ten').
* If you're unsure of the exact time, you can say 'I think it's around...' or 'About...' followed by an approximate time.
* Respond politely (e.g., 'You're welcome') after stating the time.

title: Chapter 4: Basic Vocabulary - Common Objects
description: Expand vocabulary to include common objects around the house, classroom, and city. Learn nouns for everyday items and practice describing their location and quantity. Focus on visual aids and memory techniques for vocabulary retention.

conversations.title: Identifying Objects in a Room
conversations.description: A simple conversation to practice identifying common objects in a room and using basic nouns.
conversations.instructions:
You are a teacher in a classroom. Point to different objects and ask your student what they are called. The student should respond with the correct noun.

Teacher: (Points to a table) What is this?
Student: (Responds with 'It is a table.')
Teacher: (Points to a chair) What is this?
Student: ... Continue with 'book', 'window', 'door', and 'lamp'.
Focus on clear pronunciation and correct article usage (a/an).

conversations.title: Locating Objects with Prepositions
conversations.description: Practice using prepositions of location to describe where objects are in relation to each other.
conversations.instructions:
You are playing a game with a friend where you describe the location of objects in a room. Take turns asking and answering questions.

Person A: Where is the book?
Person B: The book is on the table.
Person A: Where is the lamp?
Person B: The lamp is next to the chair.

Use a variety of objects and prepositions to practice. Focus on accurate preposition usage and clear descriptions.

conversations.title: Describing Quantity of Countable Nouns
conversations.description: Practice using numbers and quantifying countable nouns like books, chairs, and pens.
conversations.instructions:
You are inventorying supplies in a classroom. Ask and answer questions about the number of different items.

Person A: How many books are there?
Person B: There are three books.
Person A: How many chairs are there?
Person B: There is one chair.

Focus on using the correct plural forms and 'is/are' agreement.

conversations.title: Describing Objects with Adjectives
conversations.description: Use descriptive adjectives to describe common objects and practice forming complete sentences.
conversations.instructions:
You are helping someone pack their belongings and need to describe the objects. Take turns describing items for the other person to identify.

Person A: The box is big and red.
Person B: Is it the box on the table?
Person A: Yes, that's right.
Person B: The book is old and heavy.
Person A: Is it the book on the floor?
Person B: Yes.

Focus on using descriptive adjectives and accurate sentence structure.

conversations.title: Combining Vocabulary - Shopping for Objects
conversations.description: A more complex conversation involving identifying, locating, and quantifying objects in a shopping scenario.
conversations.instructions:
You are at a department store shopping for furniture and home goods. Ask the store clerk for assistance in finding specific items.

Shopper: Do you have any small tables?
Clerk: Yes, we have several. How many do you need?
Shopper: I need two. Where can I find them?
Clerk: They are in aisle three, near the lamps.
Shopper: How much is the large blue lamp?
Clerk: That is $50.
Shopper: That's a little expensive. Thank you.

Focus on combining previously learned vocabulary and phrases in a realistic context.

title: Chapter 5: Simple Verbs - 'To Be' and 'To Have'
description: Learn the conjugations of the verbs 'to be' and 'to have' in the present tense. Practice using these verbs to describe yourself, others, and possessions. Focus on subject-verb agreement and forming simple sentences.

conversations.title: Introductions using 'To Be'
conversations.description: Simple introductions focusing on the verb 'to be' and basic personal information. Practice forming sentences using 'I am', 'You are', 'He is', 'She is', 'It is'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to meet someone new.
* Practice introducing yourself and asking the other person about themselves using the verb 'to be'.
* Include information like your name, where you are from, and your occupation.
* Examples: 'I am [Name].', 'You are [Name].', 'I am from [Country].', 'You are [Occupation].'

conversations.title: Describing People using 'To Be'
conversations.description: Describing people using 'to be' and simple adjectives. Practicing 'He is', 'She is', 'They are', and agreeing/disagreeing with descriptions.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be discussing someone you both know.
* Practice describing the person using 'to be' and simple adjectives.
* Example: 'He is tall.', 'She is happy.', 'They are young.'
* React naturally to the other person's descriptions, agreeing or disagreeing and providing your own observations.
* Examples: 'Yes, he is very tall!', 'I don't think she is sad, she is usually happy.'

conversations.title: Describing Objects using 'To Be'
conversations.description: Describing objects using 'to be' and simple adjectives. Practicing 'It is' and describing properties such as color, size, and shape.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be discussing an object you both see.
* Practice describing the object using 'It is' and simple adjectives.
* Example: 'It is red.', 'It is big.', 'It is round.'
* Ask questions to clarify the other person's description.
* Example: 'Is it very big?', 'What color is it exactly?'

conversations.title: Talking about Possessions using 'To Have'
conversations.description: Talking about possessions using 'to have'. Practice using 'I have', 'You have', 'He has', 'She has' to express ownership.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be discussing your possessions with a friend.
* Practice talking about what you and others have using 'to have'.
* Example: 'I have a car.', 'He has a house.', 'Do you have any pets?'
* Ask questions about the other person's possessions.
* Example: 'What kind of car do you have?', 'How much money do you have?'

conversations.title: Describing Family and Relationships
conversations.description: Combining 'to be' and 'to have' to describe family and relationships. Using possessives (e.g., 'my brother', 'her sister') and adjectives to describe family members.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be introducing your family to someone or describing a family dynamic.
* Use 'to be' and 'to have' to describe your family and relationships.
* Examples: 'My brother is tall.', 'I have two sisters.', 'She is my wife.', 'He has a good relationship with his father.'
* Ask the other person about their family and relationships using 'to be' and 'to have'.
* Example: 'Do you have any siblings?', 'Is your mother tall?'

title: Chapter 6: Personal Pronouns and Possessives
description: Understand and use personal pronouns (I, you, he, she, it, we, they) and possessive pronouns (my, your, his, her, its, our, their). Practice forming sentences using these pronouns to talk about yourself and others, and indicate ownership.

conversations.title: Introductions and Basic Information
conversations.description: Practice introducing yourself and asking for basic information using personal pronouns. Focus on 'I', 'you', 'he', and 'she'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a language exchange event.
* Start by introducing yourself to a new person.
* Ask their name and where they are from.
* Respond to their introduction using personal pronouns.
* Keep the conversation brief and friendly.

Example:
You: "Hello, I'm Alex. Nice to meet you."
AI: "Hi Alex, I'm Maria. Nice to meet you too. I'm from Spain."
You: "That's interesting. I'm from Canada. Is he from Spain too?"
AI: "No, he is from Italy, and she is from Germany."

conversations.title: Describing People and their Belongings
conversations.description: Practice describing people using personal pronouns ('he', 'she', 'they') and their possessions using possessive pronouns ('his', 'her', 'their').
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a coffee shop with a friend. You are observing other people.
* Describe what you see using personal and possessive pronouns.
* Your friend will ask questions about the people.
* Respond using appropriate pronouns to describe the people and their belongings.

Example:
You: "Look at that man over there. He's reading a book."
AI: "Oh yes, what kind of book is it? Is it his?"
You: "Yes, it's his book. I think it's a novel. And look at those women; their bags are very colorful."
AI: "Are they friends?"
You: "Yes, I think they are friends."

conversations.title: Talking About Family
conversations.description: Practice talking about family relationships using personal and possessive pronouns ('we', 'our', 'my', 'your').
conversations.instructions:
* You are catching up with a colleague at work.
* Ask about their family and share information about your own.
* Use personal and possessive pronouns to refer to family members and their relationships.

Example:
You: "How is your family doing?"
AI: "They are all doing well, thank you. My brother just got married. How is your family?"
You: "That's great news! Our parents are planning a trip next month. We are all excited for them."
AI: "That sounds wonderful! Is your sister going with them?"
You: "No, she can't go. She has to work."

conversations.title: Making Plans and Discussing Possessions
conversations.description: Practice making plans and discussing possessions using all personal and possessive pronouns ('I', 'you', 'he', 'she', 'it', 'we', 'they', 'my', 'your', 'his', 'her', 'its', 'our', 'their').
conversations.instructions:
* You are chatting with a neighbor.
* Talk about upcoming plans and personal possessions.
* Use a variety of personal and possessive pronouns in your conversation.

Example:
You: "Are you going on vacation this year?"
AI: "Yes, we are! We are going to Italy. Is that your new car I saw parked outside?"
You: "Yes, it's my new car. I love its color. What are your plans in Italy?"
AI: "We plan to visit Rome and Florence. He has been there before, but it's our first time. Do they speak English there?"
You: "Yes, many people speak English."

conversations.title: Solving a Problem Together
conversations.description: Practice using personal and possessive pronouns while collaboratively solving a problem. Incorporate all pronouns learned.
conversations.instructions:
* You and a coworker are facing a problem at work with a shared project.
* Discuss the issue and brainstorm potential solutions using appropriate pronouns.
* Remember to use 'it' appropriately when referring to the problem or project.

Example:
You: "We have a problem with the presentation. Its formatting is all wrong."
AI: "Yes, I saw that. I think their computers may be incompatible with our software. What should we do?"
You: "We could try converting it to a different format. Do you think that is my responsibility, or is it yours?"
AI: "I can handle that. It is our team project, and we need to solve it together. Do they have any suggestions?"
You: "I'll ask them. Maybe their IT department has a solution. We should also back up our work."

title: Chapter 7: Asking Simple Questions
description: Learn to form basic questions using question words like 'who,' 'what,' 'where,' 'when,' 'why,' and 'how.' Practice asking and answering simple questions about personal information and everyday situations. Focus on question word order and intonation.

conversations.title: Meeting Someone New: Name and Origin
conversations.description: Practice asking and answering basic questions about someone's name and where they are from. Focus on 'What's your name?' and 'Where are you from?'
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a language exchange event.
* You want to introduce yourself to a new person and learn their name and origin.
* Begin the conversation with a greeting such as 'Hi' or 'Hello'.
* Remember to use 'What's your name?' and 'Where are you from?' to ask questions.
* Respond appropriately to their answers. Offer your name and where you are from.
* End with a polite phrase like 'Nice to meet you' or 'It's a pleasure'.

conversations.title: Asking About Occupation
conversations.description: Practice asking and answering questions about someone's job. Focus on 'What do you do?' and simple descriptions of professions.
conversations.instructions:
* Continue from the previous conversation, knowing the other person's name and origin.
* Express interest in learning more about them.
* Ask 'What do you do?' to inquire about their occupation.
* Respond appropriately to their answer, showing interest or asking follow-up questions about their job, if appropriate.
* Share what you do for a living.
* Maintain polite and friendly tone throughout the conversation.

conversations.title: Talking About Hobbies and Interests
conversations.description: Practice asking and answering questions about hobbies using 'What do you like to do?' and describing your interests.
key_terms: What do you like to do?
Hobby Vocabulary (reading, hiking, playing music, etc.)
conversations.instructions:
* Continue from the previous conversation. You know their name, origin, and occupation.
* Show interest in their leisure activities.
* Ask 'What do you like to do?' or 'What are your hobbies?'
* Share your own hobbies and interests.
* Engage with their answers by asking follow-up questions or relating to their interests.
* Keep the conversation light and friendly.

conversations.title: Discussing Daily Routines
conversations.description: Practice asking and answering questions about daily routines using 'What time do you...?' and describing typical activities.
key_terms: Daily Routine Vocabulary (wake up, eat breakfast, go to work, etc.)
conversations.instructions:
* Continue the conversation from the previous interaction.
* Show interest in learning about their daily life.
* Ask 'What time do you wake up?', 'What do you usually do in the morning/afternoon/evening?' or similar questions about their routine.
* Describe your own daily routine, including specific times and activities.
* Listen attentively and show interest in their routine.
* Keep a polite and engaging tone.

conversations.title: Discussing Future Plans
conversations.description: Practice asking about future plans using 'What are you going to do?' and expressing intentions.
key_terms: What are you going to do?
Future Plans Vocabulary (travel, study, relax, etc.)
conversations.instructions:
* Conclude the set of conversations. You have already discussed their name, origin, job, hobbies, and daily routine.
* Express interest in their future plans.
* Ask 'What are you going to do next week/month/year?' or 'What are your plans for the future?'
* Share your own future plans, using 'I'm going to...' followed by your intended activity.
* Wish them well with their plans and end the conversation politely, perhaps suggesting you meet again.
* Use phrases such as 'That sounds interesting' or 'Good luck with that' to show interest.

title: Chapter 8: Describing Your Family
description: Expand vocabulary related to family members (mother, father, siblings, etc.). Practice describing your family and talking about family relationships using simple sentences and adjectives. Focus on cultural nuances in family structures.

conversations.title: Introducing a Family Member
conversations.description: Practice introducing one family member (mother, father, brother, or sister). Focus on using simple possessive adjectives and nouns.
conversations.instructions:
* You are meeting someone new at a social event. 
* Introduce one family member to them using a simple sentence. 
* The other person will respond and ask a follow-up question (e.g., "What does your mother do?").
* Respond to their question.
* Example: You: "This is my brother, David." Other person: "Nice to meet you, David. What does he do?" You: "He is a teacher."

conversations.title: Describing Siblings
conversations.description: Expand the introduction by describing siblings with adjectives. Practice using "older" and "younger" to describe age, and simple adjectives to describe personality.
conversations.instructions:
* You are talking to a friend about your family.
* Describe your siblings, including their age relative to you (older/younger) and one adjective to describe them.
* Your friend will ask for more details about one of your siblings.
* Provide an additional detail.
* Example: You: "I have two siblings: an older brother and a younger sister. My brother is very funny." Friend: "Oh really? What does he do that's funny?" You: "He tells a lot of jokes."

conversations.title: Talking About Parents' Jobs
conversations.description: Practice discussing your parents' occupations. Use profession-related vocabulary. Focus on clarifying questions if you don't understand.
conversations.instructions:
* You are having a casual conversation with a classmate.
* The classmate asks you what your parents do for work.
* Describe each of your parents' jobs.
* The classmate might ask you what your job or career interests are.
* Example: Classmate: "What does your father do?" You: "He is a doctor. And my mother is a teacher." Classmate: "That's interesting! What do you want to be when you grow up?" You: "I would like to be a doctor."

conversations.title: Introducing Extended Family
conversations.description: Introduce members of your extended family (grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins). Practice using possessive adjectives and describing relationships.
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a family gathering and introducing your friend to your extended family.
* Point out different family members and briefly explain your relationship to them.
* Your friend will ask questions about some of your relatives.
* Answer the questions with a short description.
* Example: You: "This is my aunt, Susan, and these are my cousins, Michael and Emily." Friend: "Oh, nice to meet you all. What does your aunt do?" You: "She is a chef."

conversations.title: Describing Family Traditions
conversations.description: Describe family traditions or customs. Practice using descriptive adjectives and adverbs to make your description interesting. Touch on cultural nuances.
conversations.instructions:
* You are talking to someone from a different country about your family.
* Describe a tradition that your family has, explaining how you celebrate it.
* The other person will ask follow-up questions to understand the tradition better.
* Provide details and explain the significance of the tradition to your family.
* Example: You: "Every year, my family always has a big dinner for Christmas. It's a very old tradition." Other person: "That sounds nice! What kind of food do you eat?" You: "We eat turkey, potatoes and many vegetables. We make a special desert. We spend the whole day together."

title: Chapter 9: Daily Routines - Present Simple
description: Learn to talk about daily routines using the present simple tense. Practice describing your typical day, including activities and times. Focus on adverbs of frequency (always, sometimes, never) and time expressions.

conversations.title: Meeting Someone New: Basic Daily Routine
conversations.description: Introduce yourself and ask about the other person's basic daily routine. Focus on simple questions and answers using the present simple tense. Cover morning and evening routines.
conversations.instructions:
* You are meeting a new classmate at a coffee shop.
* Initiate a conversation and find out about their daily routine.
* Focus on the times they wake up, eat, and go to work/school.
* Use phrases like 'What time do you usually...?' and 'I usually...'
* Remember to use the present simple tense correctly.
* The other person is also interested in making new friends.

conversations.title: Detailed Morning Routine
conversations.description: Expand on the previous conversation by asking for more details about the morning routine. Include specific activities and timings. Practice using adverbs of frequency.
conversations.instructions:
* Continue the conversation from the coffee shop.
* Ask for more detail about your classmate's morning routine.
* Ask questions like 'Do you always brush your teeth before or after breakfast?' or 'How often do you check your emails in the morning?'
* Use adverbs of frequency to describe how often you do things.
* For example: 'I always brush my teeth after breakfast.'
* Focus on creating a natural and flowing conversation.

conversations.title: Weekend Routines and Differences
conversations.description: Discuss weekend routines and how they differ from weekday routines. Practice using time expressions and contrasting activities.
conversations.instructions:
* You are still at the coffee shop, continuing to get to know your classmate.
* Shift the conversation to weekend routines.
* Ask 'What do you usually do on weekends?'
* Contrast weekend and weekday routines using phrases like 'Instead of going to work, I...' or 'On weekends, I sleep in late.'
* Discuss how your routines differ and why.
* Practice using specific time expressions like 'late' and 'early'.

conversations.title: Evening and Night Routines
conversations.description: Focus on evening and night routines, including dinner, hobbies, and bedtime activities. Practice using the present simple tense in the third person.
conversations.instructions:
* You and your classmate are still chatting at the coffee shop.
* Shift focus to their evening and night routine.
* Ask 'What do you usually do after dinner?' or 'What does your roommate do before bed?'
* If comfortable, talk about a third person's routine (friend or family member) to practice the third person singular form of the present simple (he/she).
* Use phrases like 'He watches TV' or 'She reads a book before bed'.
* Pay attention to the 's' ending on verbs in the third person.

conversations.title: Comparing and Contrasting Routines: Planning an Activity
conversations.description: Compare and contrast your routines and find common interests. Use this information to suggest a shared activity. Consolidate knowledge of the present simple, adverbs of frequency, and time expressions.
conversations.instructions:
* Concluding the conversation with your new friend.
* Summarize what you've learned about each other's routines.
* Identify similarities and differences: 'We both like to read' or 'Our routines are very different on weekdays.'
* Suggest a shared activity based on common interests: 'Maybe we can go to the library together' or 'How about we grab coffee again next week?'
* Use phrases like 'That sounds fun!' or 'Let's do that!' to express agreement and solidify the friendship.
* Practice naturally using all the vocabulary and grammar learned in the previous conversations.

title: Chapter 10: Ordering Food and Drinks
description: Learn basic phrases for ordering food and drinks in a restaurant or cafe. Practice polite requests, asking about menu items, and expressing preferences. Focus on restaurant vocabulary and common food and drink names.

conversations.title: Ordering a Coffee
conversations.description: A simple conversation to practice ordering a coffee at a cafe.
conversations.instructions:
* You are the customer.
* You approach the counter at a cafe.
* You want to order a coffee.
* Practice using polite requests like 'Can I have a...?' or 'I'd like a...'.
* Ask for sugar or milk.
* Specify if you want it to have here or for takeaway.

**Example starting point:**
Customer: 'Hello, can I have a latte, please?'

conversations.title: Ordering a Sandwich and Drink
conversations.description: Ordering a sandwich and a cold drink, practicing asking about menu items.
conversations.instructions:
* You are the customer.
* You are at a cafe counter.
* You want to order a sandwich and a drink.
* Ask 'What kind of sandwiches do you have?'
* Ask about the ingredients of a particular sandwich ('What's in the tuna sandwich?').
* Ask about the price ('How much is the juice?').
* Remember to use 'please' and 'thank you'.

**Example starting point:**
Customer: 'Hello, what kind of sandwiches do you have?'

conversations.title: Ordering Lunch at a Restaurant
conversations.description: Ordering a main course and a drink, practicing polite requests and preferences.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a customer at a restaurant.
* You're ordering lunch.
* Ask the server for recommendations ('What do you recommend?').
* Specify your preference for still or sparkling water ('I'll have a water, still, please.').
* Order a main course using 'I'll have...'.
* Be polite throughout the conversation.

**Example starting point:**
Customer: 'Hello, what do you recommend?'

conversations.title: Dealing with Dietary Restrictions
conversations.description: Ordering food while informing the server about dietary restrictions.
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a restaurant.
* You have a dietary restriction (e.g., vegetarian, gluten-free).
* Inform the server about your restriction before ordering ('I'm vegetarian, what options do you have?').
* Ask if a dish contains specific ingredients ('Does the pasta contain cheese?').
* Ask if it's possible to have a dish without a certain ingredient ('Can I have the salad without croutons?').
* Be clear and polite.

**Example starting point:**
Customer: 'Hello, I'm vegetarian. What vegetarian options do you have?'

conversations.title: Ordering a Multi-Course Meal
conversations.description: Ordering an appetizer, main course, and dessert, including asking for clarification and changes.
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a restaurant and ready to order a full meal.
* Order an appetizer, main course, and dessert.
* Ask about the daily special ('What's the special today?').
* Ask for a side dish instead of another ('Can I have a salad instead of fries?').
* Order everything at once ('I'll have the soup for appetizer, the steak for the main course, and the chocolate cake for dessert').
* Politely thank the server.

**Example starting point:**
Customer: 'Hello, what's the special today?'

title: Chapter 11: Telling Time and Making Appointments
description: Master telling time using different formats (12-hour and 24-hour). Learn phrases for making appointments and scheduling meetings. Practice asking and telling time, and arranging schedules with others.

conversations.title: Asking and Telling Time (Casual)
conversations.description: Practice asking and telling time in a casual setting. Focus on basic time phrases and simple responses.
conversations.instructions:
* You are at a bus stop.
* One person asks the time and the other responds.
* Keep it brief and casual.
* Practice different times (e.g., It's half past three; It's a quarter to eight).

conversations.title: Making Plans (Informal)
conversations.description: Practice suggesting and agreeing on a time to meet up with a friend. Use 'Let's meet at...', 'How about...?', and 'See you then!'
conversations.instructions:
* You are planning to meet a friend for coffee.
* Suggest a time and place.
* Negotiate the time if necessary.
* Confirm the meeting details.
* Practice phrases like 'Let's meet at 2 pm' or 'How about 2:30?'

conversations.title: Scheduling a Doctor's Appointment
conversations.description: Practice making a doctor's appointment over the phone. Focus on providing information and confirming the appointment details.
conversations.instructions:
* You are calling a doctor's office to schedule an appointment.
* Provide your name and the reason for your appointment.
* Ask about available dates and times.
* Confirm the appointment details (date, time, doctor's name).
* Practice phrases like 'I'd like to schedule an appointment' and 'Is [date] at [time] available?'

conversations.title: Rescheduling a Meeting (Formal)
conversations.description: Practice rescheduling a meeting via email or phone. Focus on professional language and providing alternative options.
conversations.instructions:
* You need to reschedule a meeting with a colleague or client.
* Explain the reason for rescheduling.
* Propose alternative dates and times.
* Apologize for any inconvenience caused.
* Confirm the new meeting details once agreed upon.
* Use phrases like 'Due to [reason], I need to reschedule our meeting' and 'Would [alternative date/time] work for you?'

conversations.title: Arranging a Conference Call (Formal)
conversations.description: Practice arranging a conference call with participants in different time zones. Focus on clarity and providing the time in multiple formats.
conversations.instructions:
* You are arranging a conference call with participants in New York and London.
* Propose a time that works for both time zones.
* Clearly state the time in both GMT/UTC and the relevant local time zones (EST and BST/GMT).
* Confirm the participants' availability.
* Provide the dial-in number and access code.
* Use phrases like 'I propose [time] GMT' and 'That would be [time] EST/BST'.

title: Chapter 12: Describing Your Home
description: Expand vocabulary related to parts of a house and furniture. Practice describing your home and rooms, using prepositions of place (in, on, under, next to). Focus on spatial vocabulary and descriptive language.

conversations.title: Basic House Vocabulary
conversations.description: Introduces basic house vocabulary: rooms and exterior features.
conversations.instructions:
* Role-play: A asks "What's this?". B points to an image or real object and says "That's a [room/feature]".
* A should vary their questions to include: "Where is the kitchen?", "Is this the bedroom?"
* Practice pronunciation and repetition of key vocabulary.
* Start slowly and focus on accuracy.

conversations.title: Furniture Identification
conversations.description: Expands vocabulary to include common furniture items found in different rooms.
conversations.instructions:
* Role-play: A describes a room, B guesses the room and lists furniture: "I'm thinking of a room with a bed and a wardrobe. What room is it?" B: "It's a bedroom! There's also probably a bedside table and a lamp."
* Focus on associating furniture with specific rooms.
* Introduce questions like "What do you have in your living room?"
* Encourage complete sentences.

conversations.title: Prepositions of Place
conversations.description: Introduces and practices prepositions of place to describe the location of objects.
conversations.instructions:
* Role-play: A places an object and describes its location using prepositions, B guesses the location. For example: A: "The book is on the table." B: "Okay, I understand."
* A then hides the object and asks B: "Where is the book?" B: "It is under the chair."
* Start with simple locations and gradually increase complexity.
* Emphasize correct pronunciation and use of prepositions.

conversations.title: Describing a Single Room
conversations.description: Focuses on describing a single room in detail using learned vocabulary and prepositions.
conversations.instructions:
* Role-play: A chooses a room (real or imagined) and describes it to B. B asks clarifying questions to visualize the room.
* A: "In my bedroom, there is a large bed next to the window. There is a blue rug on the floor."
* B: "What color is the wardrobe? Is there a desk in the room?"
* Encourage the use of descriptive adjectives (large, small, blue, etc.).
* Focus on accurate grammar and sentence structure.

conversations.title: Describing Your Home
conversations.description: Describes an entire home, including multiple rooms and exterior features.
conversations.instructions:
* Role-play: A describes their ideal home or their current home to B. B asks questions about specific rooms or features.
* A: "My dream house is a modern apartment with a large balcony. The living room has a comfortable sofa and a big television."
* B: "How many bedrooms are there? Is there a garden? What color is the kitchen?"
* Encourage the use of diverse vocabulary and descriptive language.
* Practice fluency and natural conversation flow.
* A can describe their favorite part of the house.

title: Chapter 13: Hobbies and Interests
description: Learn vocabulary related to hobbies and leisure activities. Practice talking about your interests and asking others about theirs. Focus on verbs of liking and disliking, and expressing preferences.

conversations.title: Simple Introductions and Hobbies
conversations.description: A basic conversation to introduce yourself and ask about hobbies using simple vocabulary.
key_terms: What do you like to do?
conversations.instructions:
* You are meeting someone new at a social gathering. Introduce yourself and ask them about their hobbies.
* Focus on simple sentences and basic vocabulary.
* Keep the conversation brief (3-4 exchanges each).
* Example: "Hi, I'm [your name]. What do you like to do in your free time?"
* Listen and respond appropriately to their answer, sharing one of your own hobbies.

conversations.title: Expressing Likes and Dislikes More Formally
conversations.description: Discussing hobbies and interests, using 'I'm interested in...', 'I'm not very keen on...', and expanding on reasons why.
conversations.instructions:
* You are chatting with a colleague during lunch. Ask them about their interests using more formal phrases.
* Use phrases like "I'm interested in..." or "I'm not very keen on..."
* Provide reasons for your preferences using "because..."
* Example: "I'm quite interested in photography because I enjoy being creative."
* Aim for 5-6 exchanges each, going into a little more detail about your hobbies and interests.

conversations.title: Comparing and Contrasting Hobbies
conversations.description: Comparing your hobbies with those of a friend, using comparative language.
conversations.instructions:
* You are talking to a friend about hobbies. Compare your hobbies to theirs, highlighting similarities and differences.
* Use phrases like "Compared to...", "Similar to...", "Different from...", "More...", or "Less..."
* Example: "Compared to your hobby of gardening, my hobby of playing video games is less active."
* Elaborate on the reasons for your comparisons. Aim for 6-8 exchanges each.

conversations.title: Planning a Leisure Activity Together
conversations.description: Suggesting and agreeing on a leisure activity with a friend, taking preferences into account.
conversations.instructions:
* You are planning a weekend activity with a friend. Suggest a few options and try to agree on something you both enjoy.
* Use phrases like "Let's...", "How about...?", or "What do you think about...?"
* Be prepared to offer alternative suggestions if your initial ideas are not appealing to your friend.
* Example: "Let's go hiking this weekend. What do you think about that?"
* Aim for 7-9 exchanges, working towards a mutually agreeable activity or explaining why something won't work.

conversations.title: Discussing the Benefits of Different Hobbies
conversations.description: Discussing the benefits of different hobbies, using more advanced vocabulary and expressing opinions.
conversations.instructions:
* You are participating in a group discussion about hobbies and their benefits. Share your opinions and listen to others.
* Use adjectives like "beneficial", "rewarding", "relaxing", or "challenging" to describe the benefits of different hobbies.
* Express your opinions using phrases like "In my opinion..."
* Example: "In my opinion, reading is a very relaxing and beneficial hobby."
* Respond to other participants' opinions with thoughtful comments or questions. Aim for 8-10 exchanges each.

title: Chapter 14: Directions and Places in the City
description: Learn to give and understand directions. Expand vocabulary related to places in a city (shops, landmarks, public transportation). Practice asking for and giving directions, and describing locations.

conversations.title: Asking for Basic Directions
conversations.description: A tourist asks a local for simple directions to a nearby landmark using basic directional terms.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a local resident standing on a street corner.
* A tourist approaches you.
* Keep directions simple, using only "straight ahead", "left", and "right".
* Answer politely and concisely.
* End the conversation after giving the directions.

Tourist: "Excuse me, where is the Central Library?"

conversations.title: Giving More Detailed Directions
conversations.description: A tourist asks for directions, requiring more specific instructions including street names and landmarks.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a local resident familiar with the area.
* A tourist approaches you.
* Provide more detailed directions, using street names and landmarks as references.
* Be patient and clear in your instructions.
* Include distances in blocks when applicable.
* End the conversation after giving the directions.

Tourist: "Excuse me, how do I get to the City Museum?"

conversations.title: Directions with Prepositions of Movement
conversations.description: A person asks for directions using prepositions of movement such as 'across', 'through', and 'past'.
conversations.instructions:
* You work at an information kiosk in the city center.
* A person approaches looking for a specific place.
* Use prepositions of movement to give precise directions.
* Help the person understand their location relative to the destination.
* End the conversation after giving the directions.

Person: "Excuse me, is there a post office near here?"

conversations.title: Using Public Transportation
conversations.description: Asking for and giving directions involving public transport, including bus routes and subway lines.
conversations.instructions:
* You are waiting at a bus stop.
* A person approaches, looking confused.
* Provide directions involving bus routes or subway lines to a specific location.
* Explain which bus/train to take and where to get off.
* Include transfer information if necessary.
* End the conversation after giving the directions.

Person: "Excuse me, which bus goes to the botanical gardens?"

conversations.title: Clarifying and Confirming Directions
conversations.description: A person asks for directions, then repeats the directions back to confirm understanding, and asks clarifying questions.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a local resident, and someone has just asked you for directions.
* After giving directions, the person will try to repeat them back to you to make sure they understand, and ask for clarification.
* Correct any mistakes and provide additional helpful information if needed.
* Be patient and friendly.
* The conversation ends when the person is satisfied they understand.

Person: "Excuse me, could you tell me how to get to the art gallery?"

title: Chapter 15: Describing People - Physical Appearance
description: Learn vocabulary to describe physical appearance (hair, eyes, height, build). Practice describing people and recognizing descriptions. Focus on adjectives of appearance and agreement.

conversations.title: Describing a Friend (Simple)
conversations.description: A simple conversation where one person describes a friend's basic physical appearance to another.
conversations.instructions: Student A: Describe a friend to Student B. Focus on height, hair color, and eye color. Use simple adjectives.  Student B: Ask clarifying questions if needed.  Example: 'My friend is tall with brown hair and blue eyes.' Student B could ask: 'Is their hair long or short?' After the description, Student B guesses who Student A is describing. After guessing, switch roles.

conversations.title: Describing a Person at a Party
conversations.description: A conversation where one person describes someone they saw at a party, including clothing details.
conversations.instructions: Student A: Describe someone you saw at a party. Include height, hair color, eye color, and what they were wearing.  Student B: Ask questions about the clothing and accessories. Example: 'He was wearing a blue shirt and jeans.' Student B could ask: 'What color was the blue shirt?' or 'What kind of shoes was he wearing?'  After the description, Student B guesses who it is.  Then, switch roles.

conversations.title: Describing a Celebrity
conversations.description: Describing a celebrity including details about their build and distinctive features.
conversations.instructions: Student A: Describe a celebrity's physical appearance. Include height, hair color, eye color, build (slim, muscular, overweight), and any distinctive facial features (beard, mustache, etc.). Student B: Ask clarifying questions about specific features. Example: 'She is slim with long blonde hair and green eyes. She has a small nose.' Student B could ask: 'Is her hair curly or straight?'  After the description, Student B guesses the celebrity. Then, switch roles.

conversations.title: Reporting a Lost Person (Details)
conversations.description: Reporting a missing person to the police, providing detailed physical descriptions.
conversations.instructions: Student A: You are reporting a missing person to the police (Student B). Provide a detailed description, including age, height, weight, complexion, hair color, eye color, and any distinguishing marks (scars, tattoos, etc.). Student B: You are a police officer taking the report. Ask clarifying questions to get a complete description. Example: 'He is about 30 years old, 6 feet tall, with a medium build. He has brown hair and brown eyes.' Student B could ask: 'What was he wearing?' or 'Does he have any tattoos?' The goal is to gather as much detail as possible. After the report, switch roles.

conversations.title: Witness Account of a Crime
conversations.description: Providing a detailed physical description of a suspect to the police after witnessing a crime.
conversations.instructions: Student A: You witnessed a crime and are describing the suspect to the police (Student B). Provide a detailed description, including estimated age, height, build, hair color, eye color, clothing description, and any notable demeanor or mannerisms. Include any accessories like glasses, hats, or bags. Student B: You are a police officer taking the witness statement. Ask clarifying questions to ensure a complete and accurate description. Example: 'The suspect was a man, estimated to be in his late 20s, about 5'10", with a medium build. He had short dark hair and was wearing a black jacket.' Student B could ask: 'Can you describe the jacket in more detail?' or 'Did he have any facial hair?' Focus on accuracy and recall. After the statement, switch roles.

title: Chapter 16: Clothing and Shopping
description: Expand vocabulary related to clothing items and shopping. Practice talking about clothes, asking about prices, and making purchases. Focus on shopping phrases and currency vocabulary.

conversations.title: Basic Clothing Inquiry
conversations.description: Simple conversation asking about available clothing items in a store.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a customer entering a clothing store.
* Start by greeting the shop assistant.
* Ask what types of clothing the store has available using phrases like 'What kind of... do you have?' and 'I'm looking for...' 
* Respond to the shop assistant's initial offerings. Be general at first (e.g., "Do you have any shirts?"), then more specific (e.g., "Do you have any blue shirts?").
* Use basic clothing vocabulary (shirt, pants, dress, jacket, shoes).

A shop assistant is ready to help you...

conversations.title: Describing Clothing
conversations.description: Conversation focused on describing clothing items using adjectives and colors.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a customer who has seen something you like in the store but want to explore other options.
* Ask the shop assistant if they have the item in different colors or sizes.
* Use descriptive words (e.g., 'Do you have this shirt in a larger size?', 'Do you have these pants in blue?', 'I'm looking for a more casual jacket').
* React to the shop assistant's responses. If they don't have what you want, ask for similar items.
* Build on the previous conversation (assume you are in the same store).

The shop assistant is ready to help you further...

conversations.title: Asking About Prices
conversations.description: Conversation focused on asking about the prices of clothing items and expressing opinions on the price.
conversations.instructions:
* You are a customer interested in purchasing an item but concerned about the price.
* Ask the shop assistant about the price of specific items you inquired about in the previous conversations. Use phrases like 'How much is this?' and 'Is this on sale?'
* Express your opinion about the price, such as 'That's too expensive' or 'That's a good price'.
* If the price is too high, ask if they have anything cheaper or if there are any discounts available.
* Continue the conversation from where it left off in the previous round.

The shop assistant is available...

conversations.title: Paying for Items
conversations.description: Conversation focusing on payment methods and currency.
conversations.instructions:
* You have decided to purchase some items.
* Ask the shop assistant what payment methods they accept (e.g., 'Can I pay with a credit card?', 'Do you accept cash?').
* Inquire about the total amount due.
* Pay for your purchase and receive change, if applicable.
* Use currency vocabulary (e.g., 'Here is [amount]').
* The shop assistant is ready to process your purchase, building off prior discussions...

conversations.title: Returning an Item
conversations.description: Conversation involving returning an item and requesting a refund or exchange.
key_terms: I would like to return this
conversations.instructions:
* You are a customer returning to the store with an item you purchased earlier.
* Explain why you are returning the item (e.g., wrong size, damaged).
* State whether you want a refund or an exchange.
* Provide the receipt if requested.
* Use phrases like 'I would like to return this' or 'I would like to exchange this for a different size'.
* Ask about the store's return policy, if necessary. (Only if the shop assistant brings it up.)
* The shop assistant awaits you with the item...

title: Chapter 17: Weather and Seasons
description: Learn vocabulary related to weather conditions and seasons. Practice talking about the weather and seasons, and expressing preferences related to weather. Focus on weather expressions and climate vocabulary.

conversations.title: Basic Weather Greetings
conversations.description: A simple conversation about the weather when meeting someone. Focus on basic weather vocabulary and greetings.
conversations.instructions:
* You are meeting a friend on the street.
* Greet your friend and comment on the weather using phrases like: 'Nice day, isn't it?', 'It's quite sunny today.', 'Awful weather we're having!'
* Encourage your friend to respond and comment on the weather.
* Practice using a variety of weather-related adjectives (sunny, rainy, windy, etc.).
* End the conversation politely after a few exchanges.

conversations.title: Daily Weather Report
conversations.description: Describing today's weather in more detail and comparing it to yesterday.
conversations.instructions:
* You are talking to a coworker about the weather.
* Describe today's weather using specific details like temperature, wind, and cloud cover.
* Compare today's weather to yesterday's, using phrases like: 'It's much colder than yesterday.', 'Yesterday was sunnier.', 'The wind is stronger today than it was yesterday.'
* Ask your coworker for their opinion on the weather.
* Use a variety of weather terms, e.g., 'mild', 'overcast', 'breezy', 'torrential rain'.

conversations.title: Favorite Season and Activities
conversations.description: Discussing favorite seasons and related activities, expressing preferences.
conversations.instructions:
* You are chatting with a neighbor about your favorite seasons.
* State your favorite season and explain why you like it, mentioning weather conditions and activities you enjoy during that season.
* Ask your neighbor about their favorite season and listen to their reasons.
* Use phrases like: 'I love summer because...', 'My favorite season is autumn because...', 'I prefer winter because...'
* Discuss specific activities related to each season, like swimming in summer or skiing in winter.
* Use vocabulary related to seasonal activities and weather (e.g., 'skiing', 'snowboarding', 'swimming', 'hiking', 'gardening').

conversations.title: Travel Plans and Weather Considerations
conversations.description: Discussing travel plans and how weather might affect them. Checking weather forecasts.
conversations.instructions:
* You are discussing upcoming travel plans with a family member.
* Describe your travel plans, including the destination and time of year.
* Check the weather forecast for your destination and discuss how the weather might impact your plans. Use phrases like: 'If it rains, we'll...', 'If the weather is nice, we can...'
* Express concerns or excitement about the weather at your destination. For instance, 'I hope it doesn't rain during our vacation' or 'I'm excited to see the snow.'
* Ask your family member for their opinion on the weather forecast and how to prepare for different weather conditions.
* Use conditional sentences to plan alternative activities based on the weather.

conversations.title: Discussion on Climate Change
conversations.description: A more advanced conversation discussing climate change and its impact on weather patterns.
conversations.instructions:
* You are discussing recent extreme weather events with a colleague.
* Express your concerns about climate change and its potential impact on weather patterns.
* Discuss specific examples of extreme weather events that you have observed or heard about, such as heatwaves, floods, or droughts.
* Share your opinions on the causes of climate change and possible solutions.
* Use phrases like: 'I'm worried about...', 'It's concerning that...', 'I think we should...', 'It seems that...'
* Use vocabulary related to climate change and environmental issues (e.g., 'global warming', 'carbon emissions', 'sea-level rise', 'renewable energy').
* Respectfully listen to and respond to your colleague's opinions, even if they differ from your own.

title: Chapter 18: Past Tense - Simple Regular Verbs
description: Introduce the past simple tense for regular verbs. Learn to conjugate regular verbs in the past tense and use them to talk about past events. Practice forming past tense sentences and asking about past actions.

conversations.title: Weekend Recap
conversations.description: A simple conversation about what you did last weekend, focusing on regular past tense verbs.
conversations.instructions:
* Student A: Ask Student B about their weekend. Use questions like 'What did you do last weekend?' and 'Did you [verb]?'
* Student B: Answer Student A's questions using the past simple tense with regular verbs.  Use verbs like 'played', 'watched', 'listened', 'cleaned', and 'helped'.  Respond with full sentences. Example: 'I watched a movie last weekend.'
* Take turns asking and answering questions. Aim for at least 5 questions and answers each.
* Focus on correct pronunciation of the '-ed' ending on the verbs.

conversations.title: Yesterday's Activities
conversations.description: Discussing activities from yesterday, incorporating more variety in regular past tense verbs.
conversations.instructions:
* Student A: Ask Student B about what they did yesterday. Use questions like 'What did you do yesterday?' and 'Did you [verb] yesterday?'
* Student B: Answer Student A's questions using the past simple tense with regular verbs. Use verbs like 'walked', 'cooked', 'studied', 'worked', and 'visited'.  Provide additional details to expand on the answers. Example: 'I walked my dog in the park yesterday.'
* Student A: Ask follow-up questions based on Student B's answers. Example: 'Where did you walk your dog?'
* Student B: Answer the follow-up questions. 
* Take turns asking and answering. Aim for at least 3 questions and answers each, plus follow-up questions.
* Pay attention to intonation when asking questions.

conversations.title: Childhood Memories
conversations.description: Sharing memories from childhood, utilizing regular past tense verbs and longer sentences.
conversations.instructions:
* Student A: Ask Student B about their childhood. Use questions like 'Where did you live when you were a child?' or 'What games did you play?'
* Student B: Answer Student A's questions using the past simple tense with regular verbs. Use verbs like 'played', 'watched', 'lived', 'wanted', and 'loved'.  Try to give descriptive answers. Example: 'I lived in a small house near the beach when I was a child.'
* Student A: Ask follow-up questions to encourage more detail. Example: 'What did you love about living near the beach?'
* Student B: Answer the follow-up questions, expanding on the memories. 
* Take turns asking and answering. Aim for at least 3 questions and answers each, plus follow-up questions.
* Focus on fluency and clear communication.

conversations.title: Last Vacation
conversations.description: Describing a past vacation experience, requiring more complex sentences and varied vocabulary.
conversations.instructions:
* Student A: Ask Student B about their last vacation. Use questions like 'Where did you travel on your last vacation?' or 'What did you do there?'
* Student B: Describe their last vacation using the past simple tense with regular verbs. Use verbs like 'traveled', 'stayed', 'visited', 'explored', and 'enjoyed'. Try to give a detailed account of the trip. Example: 'I traveled to Italy on my last vacation. I stayed in a hotel in Rome and visited the Colosseum.'
* Student A: Ask follow-up questions to learn more about the vacation. Example: 'What did you enjoy most about visiting the Colosseum?'
* Student B: Answer the follow-up questions, providing more details and personal opinions. 
* Take turns asking and answering. Aim for at least 3 questions and answers each, plus follow-up questions.
* Focus on using descriptive language and creating a vivid picture of the vacation.

conversations.title: Discussing a Historical Event
conversations.description: Discussing a historical event, practicing past simple with regular verbs in a more formal context.
conversations.instructions:
* Student A: Start the conversation by asking Student B about a specific historical event (e.g., the invention of the telephone, the first moon landing). Use questions like 'When did the invention of the telephone happen?' or 'What changes did this invention cause?'
* Student B: Respond using the past simple tense with regular verbs. Use verbs like 'happened', 'started', 'ended', 'affected', and 'influenced'. Provide factual information and discuss the event's impact. Example: 'The invention of the telephone happened in 1876. It started a revolution in communication.'
* Student A: Ask follow-up questions to delve deeper into the historical event. Example: 'How did the telephone affect people's lives at that time?'
* Student B: Answer the follow-up questions, providing further insights and analysis. 
* Take turns asking and answering, focusing on different aspects of the chosen historical event. Aim for at least 3 questions and answers each, plus follow-up questions.
* Pay attention to accuracy and clarity when discussing the historical event. Use specific dates and names where appropriate.

title: Chapter 19: Past Tense - Simple Irregular Verbs
description: Learn common irregular verbs in the past simple tense. Practice conjugating and using irregular verbs to describe past experiences. Focus on memorizing common irregular verb forms and usage.

conversations.title: Meeting a New Friend: Past Experiences
conversations.description: A conversation where two people meet and share brief stories about their past experiences using simple irregular verbs. Focus on verbs like 'met', 'saw', 'went', 'ate', 'drank'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to meet someone new at a coffee shop.
* One person starts by asking a simple question about their day or weekend.
* The other person responds using past simple irregular verbs to describe what they did (e.g., 'I went to the park,' or 'I saw a great movie').
* Take turns asking and answering questions, focusing on using the verbs: 'met', 'saw', 'went', 'ate', and 'drank'.
* Keep the conversation short, focusing on clear and simple sentences.

conversations.title: Weekend Recap: Detailed Past Events
conversations.description: A conversation where two friends discuss their weekends in detail using various irregular verbs. Practice with verbs such as 'slept', 'found', 'gave', 'took', 'came'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be two friends catching up on Monday morning.
* One person asks the other about their weekend.
* The other person describes their weekend using past simple irregular verbs, going into more detail than the previous conversation (e.g., 'I slept in late,' or 'I found a really interesting book').
* Use the verbs: 'slept', 'found', 'gave', 'took', and 'came' naturally within the conversation.
* Ask follow-up questions to encourage more detailed responses.

conversations.title: Sharing Childhood Memories: Irregular Verb Usage
conversations.description: Two people share a childhood memory, incorporating several irregular verbs. Emphasis on using 'knew', 'thought', 'felt', 'had', 'made'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be two old acquaintances reminiscing about their childhoods.
* One person starts by mentioning something that reminds them of their childhood.
* The other person responds by sharing a specific childhood memory using past simple irregular verbs (e.g., 'I knew a girl who...', or 'I thought the ice cream man was amazing').
* Focus on using 'knew', 'thought', 'felt', 'had', and 'made' naturally in the storytelling.
* Encourage the other person to ask questions for more details about the memory.

conversations.title: Travel Story: Extended Narrative with Irregular Verbs
conversations.description: One person tells a story about a past travel experience, using a wider range of irregular verbs. Practice with verbs like 'flew', 'drove', 'saw', 'bought', 'felt', 'understood'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be someone recounting a travel experience to a friend.
* The speaker begins telling a story about a trip they took.
* Use a variety of past simple irregular verbs to describe the experience (e.g., 'I flew to Rome,' or 'I saw the Colosseum').
* Include the verbs: 'flew', 'drove', 'saw', 'bought', 'felt', and 'understood'.
* Vary sentence structure and add descriptive details to make the story engaging.
* The listener should ask clarifying questions about the story.

conversations.title: Discussing a Historical Event: Complex Irregular Verb Use
conversations.description: Two people discuss a historical event, focusing on using irregular verbs to describe the event's impact and consequences. Emphasis on using 'began', 'became', 'broke', 'led', 'knew'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be two people discussing a historical event you both are familiar with (e.g., The French Revolution, World War II).
* One person starts by mentioning the event.
* Both people contribute to the conversation, using past simple irregular verbs to describe the event's key moments and outcomes (e.g., 'The war began in 1939,' or 'The revolution led to...').
* Focus on using the verbs: 'began', 'became', 'broke', 'led', and 'knew' within the discussion.
* Try to analyze the significance of the event and its lasting impact.
* Use more complex sentence structures and vocabulary to demonstrate a deeper understanding.

title: Chapter 20: Past Experiences - Telling Stories
description: Practice using the past simple tense to tell short stories about past experiences. Focus on sequencing events, using time connectors (first, then, after), and developing narrative skills.  Learn to engage in basic storytelling.

conversations.title: My Weekend Trip
conversations.description: A simple conversation where one person recounts a recent weekend trip using the past simple tense and basic time connectors.
conversations.instructions:
Student A: You went on a short weekend trip last week. Tell Student B about your trip. Use the past simple tense. Start by saying where you went. Use 'First, then, after' to describe the sequence of events. For example: 'First, I went to the beach. Then, I swam in the sea. After that, I ate ice cream.'
Student B: Listen to Student A's story and ask at least three follow-up questions about the trip. For example: 'Where did you stay?', 'What did you eat?', 'Did you have fun?'

conversations.title: A Funny Thing Happened
conversations.description: A conversation where one person tells a short, funny story from their past, focusing on using descriptive language and the past simple tense.
conversations.instructions:
Student A: Tell Student B a short, funny story that happened to you in the past. Use the past simple tense. Try to use descriptive language to make the story more engaging. For example: 'I was walking down the street when suddenly...' 
Student B: Listen to Student A's story. Ask at least three follow-up questions to get more details about the story. Show interest and laugh where appropriate. For example: 'What happened next?', 'How did you feel?', 'What did other people do?'

conversations.title: My First Time...
conversations.description: A conversation about a 'first time' experience. Emphasizes specific details, emotional reactions, and the use of adverbs to enhance the narrative.
conversations.instructions:
Student A: Tell Student B about a 'first time' experience you had. It could be your first time traveling alone, first time cooking, first time speaking in public, etc. Use the past simple tense. Describe your emotional reactions using words like 'nervous', 'excited', 'scared', 'happy'. Use adverbs to describe how you did things (e.g., 'I quickly ran to the gate').
Student B: Listen carefully to Student A's story. Ask questions to understand the situation better. For example: 'Why were you nervous?', 'How did you prepare?', 'Would you do it again?'

conversations.title: A Memorable Day
conversations.description: A more complex conversation about a memorable day, incorporating more advanced vocabulary and longer sequences of events.
conversations.instructions:
Student A: Describe a memorable day from your past. This could be a happy day, a sad day, or just a significant day for you. Use the past simple tense and try to use more advanced vocabulary. Describe the sequence of events in detail. Use phrases like 'It all started when...', 'The next thing I knew...', 'In the end...'
Student B: Listen to Student A's story. After they finish, summarize the story in your own words. Ask questions about specific details that were unclear or that you found particularly interesting. For example: 'What made the day so memorable?', 'What was the biggest challenge you faced?', 'How did you feel at the end of the day?'

conversations.title: A Travel Adventure
conversations.description: A detailed recounting of a travel adventure, focusing on vivid descriptions, dramatic moments, and reflection on the experience.
conversations.instructions:
Student A: Tell Student B about a travel adventure you had. This could be a backpacking trip, a road trip, a cruise, etc. Use the past simple tense. Provide vivid descriptions of the places you visited and the people you met. Focus on any dramatic moments or unexpected challenges you encountered. At the end of the story, reflect on the experience and what you learned from it.
Student B: Listen carefully to Student A's story. Take notes if necessary. After they finish, ask questions about the story, focusing on the emotional impact of the experience and any lessons learned. For example: 'What was the most challenging part of the trip?', 'What was your favorite moment?', 'How did the trip change you?'

title: Chapter 21: Future Tense - Simple Plans and Intentions
description: Introduce the simple future tense (using 'will' or 'going to') for plans and intentions. Practice talking about future plans and making predictions. Focus on distinguishing between 'will' and 'going to' and expressing future actions.

conversations.title: Coffee Shop Chat: Weekend Plans
conversations.description: Two friends meet at a coffee shop and discuss their weekend plans using 'going to'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be Alex or Ben. 
* If Alex, ask Ben about his weekend plans using 'going to'. Be genuinely interested and follow up with questions. 
* If Ben, share your plans to visit your family, relax at home, and watch a movie. Use 'going to' correctly.
* Maintain a casual and friendly tone.
* Examples of questions Alex can ask: "What are you going to do this weekend?", "Are you going to visit your family?", "What movie are you going to watch?"
* Examples of answers Ben can give: "I'm going to visit my family.", "I'm going to relax at home.", "I'm going to watch a new movie on Netflix."

conversations.title: Dinner Conversation: Elaborating on Plans
conversations.description: Two friends are having dinner and expanding on their weekend plans, including specific details.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be Alex or Ben. This conversation follows the previous one.
* If Alex, remember Ben's plans from the previous conversation and ask for more specific details about the restaurant and the movie, use 'going to'.
* If Ben, provide specific details such as the name of the restaurant and the type of movie, use 'going to' when referring to established plans, and use 'will' to make spur-of-the-moment decisions or predictions.
* Maintain a friendly tone.
* Examples of questions Alex can ask: "Which restaurant are you going to go to with your family?", "What kind of movie are you going to watch?", "Will you try anything new on the menu?".
* Examples of answers Ben can give: "We're going to eat at 'The Italian Place'.", "I think we're going to watch an action movie.", "I will probably try the lasagna."

conversations.title: Travel Agent: Booking a Trip
conversations.description: A person talks to a travel agent about their future travel plans, using 'will' and 'going to'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be the traveler or the travel agent.
* If you are the traveler, you want to book a trip to a beach destination. Use 'going to' to express your intentions and 'will' to ask for suggestions or make quick decisions.
* If you are the travel agent, provide information about available destinations, flights, and hotels. Use 'will' to make promises or predictions.
* Be polite and helpful.
* Examples of questions (Traveler to Agent): "I'm going to book a trip to the beach. Where do you suggest I go?", "Will the weather be good in July?", "I think I will choose this hotel.".
* Examples of answers (Agent to Traveler): "I recommend Cancun. It's beautiful!", "The weather will be perfect in July.", "Great choice! I will book it for you."

conversations.title: Work Meeting: Project Timeline
conversations.description: Colleagues discuss the timeline for a new project, using 'will' and 'going to' for deadlines and tasks.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be Project Manager (Sarah) or Team Member (David).
* If you are Sarah, lead the meeting and discuss the project timeline. Assign tasks using 'will' and confirm intentions using 'going to'.
* If you are David, ask clarifying questions about your responsibilities. Use 'will' to confirm your commitment.
* Maintain a professional tone.
* Examples of questions (David to Sarah): "When are we going to have the first draft ready?", "Will I be responsible for the presentation?".
* Examples of answers (Sarah to David): "We're going to aim for the end of the week.", "Yes, you will prepare the presentation.", "I will need your feedback by tomorrow."

conversations.title: Making Predictions: Future Technologies
conversations.description: Two people discuss future technologies and make predictions using 'will'.
conversations.instructions:
* You are pretending to be Person A or Person B.
* If Person A, initiate the discussion by asking about Person B's predictions for future technologies.
* If Person B, share your predictions using 'will' and justify your predictions. Ask Person A for their opinions.
* Be creative and imaginative.
* Examples of questions (Person A to Person B): "What technologies do you think will be popular in the future?", "Will we have flying cars?", "Do you think robots will replace humans?".
* Examples of answers (Person B to Person A): "I think we will have more advanced AI. I think it's inevitable.", "I don't think we will have flying cars. They seem impractical.", "Robots will probably assist humans but not completely replace them. What do you think?"
* Use vocabulary related to science and technology.
